G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28 provides in relevant part that the Court may “from time to time, upon a complaint after a divorce, revise and alter its judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children” as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Where the parents were never married or were not divorced in Massachusetts, the Probate and Family Court likewise has continuing authority to modify custody and parenting-time provisions under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as applicable, and the general equity jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time determinations is the “best interests of the child.” See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time determinations is the “best interests of the child.” See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses and reaffirms that Massachusetts custody decisions are governed by the “best interests of the child” standard. It traces the history of the doctrine, cites prior Massachusetts cases using that formulation, and explains that G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) incorporates and does not replace the paramount best-interests inquiry in custody determinations. This directly supports citing Custody of Kali for the proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: In evaluating best interests, courts consider, among other things, the child’s safety, emotional and physical well‑being, the stability of each parent, and the effect of any proposed change in custody or parenting time. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child in custody determinations. While that necessarily implicates the child’s safety and well‑being as part of the best‑interests analysis, the court does not set out a broader list that includes the stability of each parent and the effect of any proposed change in custody or parenting time. Thus, it supports the narrower point that domestic violence and its impact on the child must be considered, but not the fuller, multi‑factor formulation stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).proposition: The Court is authorized to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013); Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns modification of child support orders, not custody or parenting-time orders. The court explicitly explains that, after the 1993 amendment to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard applies to custody modifications, while a different ‘inconsistency’ standard governs child support modifications. Thus, Morales is authority for the inconsistency standard in child support cases, not for the proposition that custody/parenting-time orders are modified upon a material and substantial change and best interests of the child.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013).relevant_excerpt: “The point is reinforced by the history of § 28. Prior to its amendment in 1993…§ 28 provided that the material and substantial change standard was the correct standard for determining whether to modify a custody judgment or a child support order…The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court is authorized to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the child’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507 (2013); Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards for making an initial custody award in a divorce judgment, focusing on the best interests/welfare of the child and the need for appropriate findings. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor does it address any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment. Therefore, it does not support the specific two-prong modification standard stated in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834.raw_text: Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834 (2020)
Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that issues of parental substance abuse or impairment that affect the child’s safety or welfare can constitute such a material change in circumstances and justify modification of custody or parenting time. See Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834 (2020); Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).

Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that issues of parental substance abuse or impairment that affect the child’s safety or welfare can constitute such a material change in circumstances and justify modification of custody or parenting time. See Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834 (2020); Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).support_reasoning: This decision is a care-and-protection/termination-of-parental-rights case focused on physical abuse, cognitive limitations, and DCF’s reasonable efforts, not on parental substance abuse or impairment as a changed circumstance for modifying custody or parenting time. The opinion does not discuss substance use, intoxication, or similar impairment, nor does it analyze material changes in circumstances in the context of post‑judgment custody or parenting-time modification. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about substance abuse as a material change justifying modification.
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011).relevant_excerpt: In deciding whether to terminate a parent’s rights, a judge must determine whether there is clear and convincing evidence that the parent is unfit and, if the parent is unfit, whether the child’s best interests will be served by terminating the legal relation between parent and child. … Considering the longstanding pattern of physical abuse, the impact of the mother’s cognitive limitations, the lack of significant improvement in her parenting, and her continued failure to come to grips with the problems in her relationship with her daughter … the judge did not clearly err in finding that the mother was unfit and that her unfitness was not temporary.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that issues of parental substance abuse or impairment that affect the child’s safety or welfare can constitute such a material change in circumstances and justify modification of custody or parenting time. See Adoption of Helga, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 834 (2020); Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53 (2011); Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: This decision is about standards and procedures for removing custody from a natural parent in a care-and-protection/guardianship posture. It discusses parental unfitness, best interests, lifestyle, and evidentiary standards, but it does not address substance abuse, impairment, or modification of existing custody or parenting-time orders based on later-arising substance issues. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that parental substance abuse constituting a material change in circumstances can justify modification of custody or parenting time.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection… It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself. As parens patriae the State does not act to punish misbehaving parents; rather it acts to protect endangered children.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Court has broad equitable discretion to structure parenting time, including imposing supervision or conditions, in order to protect the child’s welfare while permitting an ongoing relationship with both parents where appropriate. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844–845; Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the Probate Court judge’s broad discretion in custody matters under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not address imposing supervision or specific conditions on parenting time to protect the child while preserving relationships with both parents. Instead, the case focuses on whether separating twins between parents (split physical custody) was supported by the evidence and concludes the judge overrelied on the children’s preferences. It is therefore about evidentiary support and the best-interests analysis in split-custody decisions, not about supervised or conditional parenting time structures.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… ‘The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests “is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”’ … Discretion allows the judge, when determining the best interests of children, to consider the widest range of permissible evidence…”}

Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that when there is credible evidence of parental substance abuse or conduct that may endanger the child, the Court must give primacy to the child’s safety and well‑being over a parent’s interest in unrestricted access. See Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on termination of parental rights, post‑adoption contact, and the Probate Court’s equitable authority; it does not articulate a general rule that courts must give primacy to child safety over parental access when there is evidence of substance abuse or endangerment. Although the facts involve severe maternal drug abuse and unfitness, the quoted portions do not frame this as a balancing between safety and a parent’s interest in access, nor do they discuss visitation limitations premised on safety concerns. Thus, using this case for that specific proposition overstates what it actually holds.
Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).relevant_excerpt: She found that Vito’s mother’s drug abuse and resultant neglect “was severe and of a lengthy duration,” although she had improved in the last two years. … The judge concluded that, by clear and convincing evidence, Vito’s mother is currently unfit to parent him. She specifically found that the biological mother “lacks the current ability, capacity, fitness and readiness” to parent Vito. Her unavailability to Vito, she concluded, resulted in Vito’s “life-long placement with [his foster] family, to which he is now attached.” … “[g]ood intentions ... are insufficient to establish fitness to parent a child.”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have emphasized that when there is credible evidence of parental substance abuse or conduct that may endanger the child, the Court must give primacy to the child’s safety and well‑being over a parent’s interest in unrestricted access. See Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for findings of parental unfitness, the necessity of specific findings, and best‑interests analysis regarding placement and sibling relationships. It does not discuss parental substance abuse or frame the analysis as giving primacy to child safety over a parent’s interest in unrestricted access, nor does it balance visitation rights against safety concerns. The case emphasizes careful judicial findings, keeping siblings together, and family placement where possible, rather than articulating a rule that safety must override parental access in the face of substance abuse or dangerous conduct.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “The removal of a child from the custody of his of her parent may be ordered only if there is clear and convincing evidence that the parent is currently unfit to care for that child… In addition, the judge’s findings of fact must be particularly specific and detailed… They may not be based on inappropriate factors, such as disapproval of a parent’s life-style or a comparison of the material opportunities a foster parent may offer with those offered by a natural parent.”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 682–683 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.proposition: The material change in circumstances requirement ensures stability while permitting the Court to respond appropriately when the factual underpinnings of the original judgment have significantly changed. See Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 682–683 (2016); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Rosen does discuss why G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a) limits retroactive modification of support and emphasizes finality and judicial oversight, but it does not frame this in terms of the familiar “material change in circumstances” standard or describe that requirement as balancing stability with responsiveness to changed facts. The case is focused on whether equitable credits for arrears are permissible despite the statutory bar, not on articulating the purpose of the material-change requirement. Thus, Rosen only indirectly relates to the proposition and does not clearly stand for it.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 6.relevant_excerpt: “In enacting § 13(a), ‘the Legislature limited the power of a judge to reduce retroactively any arrearages in child support except for any period during which there is a pending complaint for modification.’ … ‘The object of § 13(a) was to give support orders the finality of other judgments, to assist the [Department of Revenue] in its enforcement efforts.’ … By implicitly prohibiting extrajudicial modifications of child support, § 13(a) furthers the Commonwealth’s policy of requiring court oversight for all agreements pertaining to child support.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The material change in circumstances requirement ensures stability while permitting the Court to respond appropriately when the factual underpinnings of the original judgment have significantly changed. See Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677, 682–683 (2016); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence in Smith v. McDonald is focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute, the mother’s sole legal custody before adjudication, and the inapplicability of the Yannas ‘removal’ framework. It discusses stability and preserving the status quo, but does not address or articulate any ‘material change in circumstances’ requirement, nor does it describe that requirement as a mechanism to ensure stability while allowing response to changed factual underpinnings. Thus, this case does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…')."
